options.systemMessage: You are an expert in conversation summaries and creating a version that will act as the knowledge base for a future conversation with an AI voice agent. When producing the output, just provide the comprehensive summary, no introduction, in long prose and containing all pertinent details. Make sure to log all facts. This summary will be written to a knowledge base and further consolidated so make it a more verbose version.

googleApi.name: Google Service Account - Edu account Oct 8th

parameters.text:
=Latest Conversation Summary: {{ $('Create new single conv summary').item.json.output }}
Prior conversation Summaries: {{ $('Set fields pre agent').item.json["Prior Conversation History"] }}

options.systemMessage:
=You are an expert in taking a series of conversations summaries and consolidating them into a single output which is a consolidated version ready to act as a knowledge base for a voice AI agent. 

You should make sure to use as much detail as possible from each conversation. You should prioritising information from the Latest Call Summary ({{ $('Create new single conv summary').item.json.output }}) and consider this to be more up to date and needed verbatim, whilst looking for links and relevance from the prior call Summaries ({{ $('Search existing records by email ID').item.json['Conversation History'] }}) 

The aim is to ensure the knowledge base has a bias for more up to date information. When producing the single output, just provide the detailed summary, no introduction, in long prose and containing all pertinent details. Make sure to include as much detail as possible, linking relevant points to provide a robust history of the conversation. 

Keep the total output to a digestible size for a leading LLM to avoid excess latency. The content will be machine only readable so make it the most effective and accurate source of information charecter for character.

googleApi.name: Google Service Account - Edu account Oct 8th

options.systemMessage:
=You are an expert in extracting client names from a series of converations ({{ $('Conv history agent').item.json.output }}) ready to act as a knowledge base for a voice AI agent. 

The aim is to ensure the knowledge base has a comprehensive list of all clients, firms and companies this lawyer has worked for or represented.

The output should be a very concise list of clients separated by commas in a single short text stream, ranked in a weighted order of relevance with the most relevant first.

googleApi.name: Google Service Account - Edu account Oct 8th

options.systemMessage:
=You are an expert in extracting short and concise matter summaries from a lawyer's converation history ({{ $('Conv history agent').item.json.output }}) ready to act as a knowledge base for a voice AI agent. The matter summaries should each contain the client's name and a brief description of the matter, maximum 50 works per matter and separate each matter with a comma. The output should be ranked in a weighted order of relevance with the most relevant first.

The aim is to ensure the knowledge base has a comprehensive list of all matters this lawyer has worked on.

fields.Call Summary: The AI agent and user Andy discussed a new matter for a Chambers submission. The matter involved The Entertainer, a toy shop, seeking to compete with Chinese markets by establishing a new route to market from Finland, focusing on tax rebates and supply chain logistics. The value of the matter was 1.273 million euros, involving the UK and Finland. Andy from the London office, cross-border tax practice group, was the lead lawyer. The matter started in January 2025 and is ongoing. The agent confirmed the details and completed the submission.

Conversation History.value:
Andy Batty (andy@legalengine.co.uk) is a lead lawyer engaged in his department's AI agent development. He operates from two primary locations, splitting his time between the Hamburg office for Brewdog-related matters and the London office for Just Eat matters. On November 22, 2025, at 12:20:09 UTC, Andy interacted with an AI agent for 223 seconds, incurring a cost of 2796 units, to update matter details, authenticating via Microsoft SSO before the call concluded due to a client disconnection after he selected the "Brewdog HR/employment advice" case. A day prior, on November 21, 2025, Andy experienced technical issues with an AI agent and was presented with a list of generic matters before disconnecting without selection.

One of the significant matters is a strictly confidential, cross-border divorce case for a "Wife and hotelier client." This ongoing matter commenced on January 1, 2025, with the final hearing anticipated in September 2025. The core of the matter involves complex financial proceedings where the husband underwent gender transition, raising a novel point of law regarding whether marital assets could fund his transition to female property, which is cited as a precedent-setting element. The department has acted comprehensively for the wife, addressing multi-jurisdictional assets, contested interim maintenance, legal expenses, asset disclosure, and freezing orders. The financial value of this matter was recently confirmed and updated to 4 million sterling, having previously been stated within a range of 3-4 million. The case spans multiple jurisdictions, including the UK, Italy, USA, Switzerland, Germany, Argentina, and Morocco, where a hotel business is located. Hetty Gleave, based in Fladgate's London office within the Matrimonial Finance practice group, is the lead lawyer, a detail that was confirmed as unchanged. The Fladgate team also includes Patrick Buck and Isabel McGregor, both based in London. Other firms involved are Keystone Law, acting as adverse counsel, and B and M Law, providing Italian legal advice. Additionally, barristers from 29 Bedford Row were involved, though the name of a King's Counsel (KC) was not provided due to confidentiality. Work over the last 12 months has brought the matter closer to its conclusion, with the final hearing approaching. This work included managing divorce and financial proceedings, responding to the husband's non-compliance with maintenance orders, attempts to drain finances, non-disclosure, enforcement proceedings, freezing order applications/defense, and navigating challenges from the Moroccan earthquake. Due to its confidential nature, there is no press coverage for this matter. The most recent interaction regarding this matter occurred on 2025-11-22T18:14:06.000Z, lasting 508 seconds and costing 6103 units (172 LLM, 5931 call).

Andy also leads the "Brewdog HR/employment advice" matter, which is not confidential, is publishable, and remains ongoing since its commencement in January 2020. This domestic UK matter for client Brewdog recently saw its financial value increase from 700,000 to 1 million Sterling. Andy Batty leads this case from the Hamburg office, operating within the Microscopic Law Technology practice group. Over the past 12 months, work has primarily focused on tax efficiency and improving Brewdog's profitability within a private equity deal, specifically by closing real estate locations and concentrating on high-visibility iconic sites like Waterloo. Previously reported work included protecting Brewdog's business, providing ongoing leadership support, conducting in-depth analysis for business optimization, and navigating the UK media landscape in the context of a private equity investment. The team includes Lucy Batty (Camberley office, tax expertise), Lee Curtis (Data Protection, Durban, who replaced Simon Martin who was previously in Dublin for Transactional Due Diligence), Boris Hernikoff (Employment Legal, Frankfurt), and Barry White (Data Protection, Dubai). No other law firms are involved. Press coverage has been noted in BBC Online, the Financial Times, and the Daily Mail.

Furthermore, Andy leads the "Just Eat Takeaway.com acquisition by iFood" matter, which began on February 1, 2020, for client Just Eat Takeaway.com. This ongoing, publishable, and non-confidential cross-border M&A transaction has seen its value increase from 2.75 million to 3 million Sterling. Considered precedent-setting, it involves a Brazilian company acquiring a European business, reflecting a global trend of transition from European-focused startups to larger conglomerates. Andy is based in London for this matter. His work in the last 12 months involved active collaboration with iFood to integrate their technology platforms into a single corporate technology stack, including extensive consultation on the legal implications of operating such a unified stack across South America and Europe, specifically addressing European jurisdictional perceptions of a "one-size-fits-all" technological approach. A particular focus was placed on generative AI application, leveraging Andy's involvement in AI agent development. Earlier work facilitated the transition from Just Eat, understanding acquired assets, and planning future collaboration. The transaction required compliance with FCA rules and engagement with the European Commission, and involved banks such as Avian Amro, Royal Bank of Brazil, and Royal Bank of Ireland. Ultimately, Just Eat Takeaway sold its stake in iFood to Prosus due to activist stakeholder pressure. The diverse jurisdictions involved include the UK, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Germany, Austria, the Czech Republic, the Netherlands, Brazil, and the newly added Rwanda, with Greece no longer included. His supporting team for this matter includes Lee Curtis (HR, Dublin, a different role and location from his Data Protection specialization for Brewdog), Charles Dickens (Data Protection, Netherlands), and Sam Stamp (HR, Hamburg). No other law firms were involved. Press coverage for this matter includes www.nbc.com, the Financial Times, BBC Online, and The Grocer, with the Financial Times and BBC Online being common outlets shared with the Brewdog matter.

Finally, Andy is also associated with a publishable, domestic UK matter for Barclays Bank concerning a comprehensive rebranding initiative. Valued at 150,000 Euros (approximately 130,000), this initiative aimed to transition Barclays from their traditional lion logo to a more AI-friendly design, reflecting their aspiration to be a digital-first challenger bank. Work over the past 12 months included managing the rebrand process, conducting due diligence, ensuring Pantone awareness, identifying relevant URLs, and performing extensive research and consumer testing to prevent brand leakage, particularly concerning the notable shift from their historical blue color scheme to a new green. The lead lawyer for this matter is based in London and specializes in Intellectual Property (IP) within a practice group focusing on IP aspects related to shapes, colours, Pantones, taglines, and imagery. Support was provided by Eduardo from the Singapore office, specializing in Market Intelligence. No other law firms were involved. Specific start date, completion status, or press coverage details for this matter were not explicitly provided.

Clients.value: REGEX_REPLACE(CONCATENATE(IF(AND({Brown Square Limited}!=".",{Brown Square Limited}!=BLANK()),{Brown Square Limited}&", ",""),IF(AND({Fladgateand Brewdog}!=".",{Fladgateand Brewdog}!=BLANK()),{Fladgateand Brewdog}&", ",""),IF(AND({Just Eat Takeaway.com}!=".",{Just Eat Takeaway.com}!=BLANK()),{Just Eat Takeaway.com}&", ",""),IF(AND({Barclays Bank}!=".",{Barclays Bank}!=BLANK()),{Barclays Bank}&", ",""),IF(AND({Legalengine}!=".",{Legalengine}!=BLANK()),{Legalengine}&", ",""),IF(AND({Microscopic Law Technology}!=".",{Microscopic Law Technology}!=BLANK()),{Microscopic Law Technology}&", ","")),", $","")

json.Previous Submissions:
**Matter Details**

*   **Reference:** PAM007
*   **Publishable Matter:** 10  Alan Karsberg
*   **Client:** Brown Square Limited
*   **Lead Lawyer:** Alan Karsberg

**Matter Summary and Department Role**
Fladgate advised Brown Square Limited on the relocation of their European corporate headquarters. Fladgate was instructed due to a long-term relationship and the clients need for expansion after outgrowing their previous space. An agreement for lease was signed in April [2025?] for new offices in the City of London, with anticipated occupation in 2028. The deal involves an annual rent of 35 million on a fifteen-year lease, with an option to extend. This transaction is noteworthy because the building will meet the highest environmental and ESG standards, and it represented the most significant occupier transaction in London last year, marking a landmark move for the client.

**Matter Value**
Annual rent of 35 million on a 15-year lease.

**Cross-Border Information**
*   **Is Cross-Border:** Yes
*   **Jurisdictions Involved:**
    *   UK (main jurisdiction)
    *   Cayman Islands (clients parent company guarantee)
    *   Gibraltar (counterparty)

**Team Members**
*   Alan Karsberg (Lead Lawyer)
*   Fiona Smith (Property)
*   Joe Kelly (Construction)
*   James Ashwin (Construction)
*   Kirsty Corcombe (Rights of Light)
*   Neal Todd (Tax)

**Other Firms and Roles**
*   Clifford Chance (advised developer and landlord)

**Status and Key Dates**
*   **Status:** ONGOING
*   **Agreement for Lease Exchanged:** April [2025?]
*   **Completion Anticipated:** 2028

**Additional Information**
Extensive coverage in React News and other property publications.

json.Prior Conversation History:
A new, strictly confidential, cross-border legal matter has been detailed by Andy Batty (andy@legalengine.co.uk) for a Chambers submission. This matter involves a wife and hotelier client whose divorce and financial proceedings became uniquely complex when her husband underwent gender transition, requiring judicial intervention to determine if marital assets could fund his transition to female property, establishing a novel point of law. The department acted comprehensively for the wife, managing multi-jurisdictional assets, addressing contested interim maintenance and legal expenses, handling asset disclosure, and dealing with freezing orders, in addition to the gender transition funding issue. Over the past 12 months, work included managing these divorce and financial proceedings and responding to the husband's non-compliance with maintenance orders, attempts to drain finances, and non-disclosure, necessitating enforcement proceedings, freezing order applications/defense, and navigating challenges from the Moroccan earthquake. The case involves multiple jurisdictions: UK, Italy, USA, Switzerland, Germany, Argentina, and Morocco, where a hotel business is located. The financial value is estimated at 4 million sterling, derived from a stated range of 3-4 million. Hetty Gleave, based in Fladgate's London office within the Matrimonial Finance practice group, is the lead lawyer. Fladgate team members include Patrick Buck (Associate, London) and Isabel McGregor (Trainee, London). Keystone Law acted as adverse counsel, with Alexis Campbell Casey, Simon Kalheim, Laura Heaton, and Michelle Minato from 29 Bedford Row also involved. B and M Law provided Italian legal advice. The matter commenced on January 1, 2025, is ongoing, and has no associated press coverage.

Andy Batty, email andy@legalengine.co.uk, is a lead lawyer involved in his department's AI agent development. He splits his time between the Hamburg office for Brewdog matters and London for Just Eat matters. On November 22, 2025, at 12:20:09 UTC, he interacted with an AI agent in a 223-second call (costing 2796 units) initiated by the agent to update matter details, authenticating via Microsoft SSO before concluding due to client disconnection. During this call, he selected the "Brewdog HR/employment advice" case for update. A prior brief call on November 21, 2025, saw Andy encounter technical issues with an AI agent, then presented with a list of generic matters (acquisition of a renewable energy company, a commercial litigation case, and a real estate transaction) before disconnecting without selection.

The "Brewdog HR/employment advice" matter, confirmed as not confidential and publishable, is for client Brewdog. It commenced in January 2020 and remains ongoing, operating under domestic UK jurisdiction. Andy Batty leads this case from the Hamburg office within the Microscopic Law Technology practice group. Its financial value recently increased from 700,000 to 1 million Sterling. Work over the past 12 months focused on tax efficiency and solving for profitability within a private equity deal, specifically improving Brewdog's profitability by closing real estate locations and concentrating on key iconic sites like Waterloo, which has high public visibility. Previously reported work included protecting Brewdog's business, providing ongoing leadership support, conducting in-depth analysis for business optimization, and navigating the UK media landscape within the private equity investment case. Lucy Batty from the Camberley office provides tax expertise. Supporting Andy are Lee Curtis (Data Protection, Durban, who replaced Simon Martin, previously in Dublin for Transactional Due Diligence), Boris Hernikoff (Employment Legal, Frankfurt), and Barry White (Data Protection, Dubai). No other law firms are involved. While no specific press coverage URLs were provided in the latest call, prior records indicate coverage in BBC Online, the Financial Times, and the Daily Mail.

Andy also leads the "Just Eat Takeaway.com acquisition by iFood" matter, which started on February 1st, 2020, with Just Eat Takeaway.com as the client. This ongoing, cross-border M&A transaction is publishable and not confidential. Its value recently increased from 2.75 million to 3 million Sterling. It is considered a precedent-setting transaction involving a Brazilian company acquiring a European business, reflecting a global trend of transition from European-focused startups to larger conglomerates. For this matter, Andy is based in London. His work over the past 12 months involved active collaboration with iFood to integrate their technology platforms into a single corporate technology stack, including extensive consultation on the legal implications of operating such a unified stack across South America and Europe, specifically addressing European jurisdictional perceptions of a "one-size-fits-all" technological approach. A particular focus was placed on generative AI application, relevant to Andy's AI agent development involvement. Earlier work facilitated the transition from Just Eat, understanding acquired assets, and planning future collaboration. The transaction required compliance with FCA rules and engagement with the European Commission, and involved banks such as Avian Amro, Royal Bank of Brazil, and Royal Bank of Ireland. Ultimately, Just Eat Takeaway sold its stake in iFood to Prosus due to activist stakeholder pressure. The diverse jurisdictions involved include the UK, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Germany, Austria, the Czech Republic, the Netherlands, Brazil, and the newly added Rwanda, with Greece no longer included. His supporting team for this matter includes Lee Curtis (HR, Dublin, a different role and location from his Data Protection specialization for Brewdog), Charles Dickens (Data Protection, Netherlands), and Sam Stamp (HR, Hamburg). No other law firms were involved. Press coverage for this matter includes www.nbc.com, the Financial Times, BBC Online, and The Grocer, with the Financial Times and BBC Online being common outlets for both Brewdog and Just Eat.

Additionally, Andy is associated with a publishable, domestic UK matter for Barclays Bank concerning a comprehensive rebranding initiative, valued at 150,000 Euros (approximately 130,000). This initiative aimed to transition Barclays from their traditional lion logo to a more AI-friendly design, reflecting their aspiration to be a digital-first challenger bank. Over the past 12 months, work included managing the rebrand process, conducting due diligence, ensuring Pantone awareness, identifying relevant URLs, and performing extensive research and consumer testing to prevent brand leakage, particularly concerning the notable shift from their historical blue color scheme to a new green. The lead lawyer for this matter, based in London, specialized in IP (Intellectual Property) within a practice group focusing on IP aspects related to shapes, colours, Pantones, taglines, and imagery. Support was provided by Eduardo from the Singapore office, specializing in Market Intelligence. No other law firms were involved, and its start date, completion status, or press coverage details were not explicitly provided.
